summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Treasury Will Auction Four-Week Bills
summary: The Treasury plans to sell $35 billion in four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Nov. 15, 2011

headline: Hitching a Ride to the International Space Station
summary: FRIENDLY COMMUTE: U.S. astronaut Dan Burbank, right, and Russian cosmonaut Anton Shkaplerov joke before boarding a Russian Soyuz spacecraft that is set to dock with the International Space Station on Wednesday. Photo: Mikhail Metzel/Press Pool

headline: Ex-CEO at CSK Auto to Return Bonus
summary: The SEC said the former head of the auto-parts retailer has agreed to return $2.8 million in bonus pay and incentives he received while his company was committing accounting fraud.

headline: Business Briefs
summary: A roundup of business briefs.

headline: Deals India: Morning News Roundup
summary: News roundup from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Wednesday, November 16, 2011. Deals India has not verified the stories from other media organizations and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: Fred Iklé
summary: A man who helped win the Cold War, and future wars too.

headline: Chevron Says Brazil Offshore Well Sealed
summary: Chevron said that it successfully contained the flow from a deep-water appraisal well offshore Brazil suspected to be at the root of an underwater oil leak.

headline: Asia in Pictures
summary: Kashmir women protest against price rises, Pakistani police search for wreckage of a crashed fighter jet, and more.

headline: Financial Briefing Book: Nov. 16
summary: Financial Briefing Book: Nov. 16

headline: Higher Costs Hit Wal-Mart
summary: Wal-Mart reported a 2.9% drop in quarterly earnings as the soft U.S. economy continued to weigh on the retailer's domestic operations and it contended with higher costs.

headline: Fed Presses Primary Dealers on Collateral
summary: The Fed said it will be increasing collateral requirements on 21 primary-dealer banks in transactions dealing with mortgage-backed securities.

headline: 'Dark Pool' Leaders Exit After SEC Case
summary: The top two executives at Pipeline Financial left the company weeks after the SEC said the "dark pool" trading platform systematically abused customer orders for years.

headline: Mexico's Lopez Obrador to Run For President in 2012
summary: The announcement ends months of uncertainty about possible split among Mexico's left-wing parties.

headline: CBS Taps Charlie Rose, Gayle King for New Show
summary: CBS News confirmed that it hired the PBS talk show host Charlie Rose and radio host Gayle King to help anchor its yet-to-be named new morning show, which debuts on Jan. 9.

headline: MF Customers Irked at 'Service Fee' Proposal
summary: Customers with funds trapped by the collapse of MF Global could be hit with additional costs as the trustee overseeing the broker-dealer's liquidation outlined potential costs for returning wire transfers.

headline: Astra's Crestor Is Comparable to Lipitor in Study
summary: AstraZeneca's Crestor cholesterol drug wasn't significantly better than rival Pfizer's Lipitor in reversing artery-clogging plaque in a clinical trial.

headline: Argentine Real Estate Hamstrung by Currency Controls
summary: Argentine real estate transactions have ground to a halt since the government imposed strict limits on the ability of people to acquire U.S. dollars two weeks ago.

headline: Iraq Approves Shell Gas Deal
summary: The Iraqi cabinet approved a deal valued at as much as $17.2 billon for Royal Dutch Shell to capture and process gas from three giant southern oil fields.

headline: Whitening Upstarts Make Dentists Gnash Teeth
summary: Four out of five dentists, it seems, believe they should handle teeth whitening. They're battling spas, tanning salons and other nondental entrepreneurs over who should be permitted to offer teeth-whitening services.

headline: RIM Adds Two Phones
summary: Research In Motion launched two new phones based on its BlackBerry 7 operating system as it tries to shore up its share of the North American smartphone market.

headline: Daqo New Energy, Telestone Technologies: Biggest Price Decliners (DQ, TSTC)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Treasury Rally Peters Out
summary: A Treasury market rally sputtered as investors rotated out of bonds and into U.S. stocks, driven partly by political progress in Italy.

headline: Headwaters, ChinaCast Education: Biggest Price Gainers (HW, CAST)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Chevron, Exxon Mobil: Money Flow Leaders (CVX, XOM)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Occupy Toronto Braces for Eviction
summary: City officials moved to bring the month-old Occupy Toronto protest in a downtown park to an end, issuing an eviction notice advising the protesters to remove all tents and immediately leave the park.

headline: 'My Shoes Are More Honorable'
summary: Tensions over the bloody conflict in Syria reached late-night television in Lebanon, when a late-night discussion between two Lebanese politicians culminated in curses and near-blows with office chairs.

headline: Debt Fears Suppress Euro
summary: Italy's soaring government bond yields pushed the euro close to a one-month low, with initial optimism over the country's new leadership overtaken by fear that Europe's debt crisis is entering a perilous new phase.

headline: Geron's Stem-Cell Exit Arose From Financial Uncertainty
summary: Geron attributed its decision to exit embryonic stem cell research to financial constraints rather than any scientific setbacks in the emerging and controversial research field.

headline: Apple Gets Some Praise in China on Environment
summary: Chinese environmental leaders offered cautious praise for Apple's attempts to meet their concerns.

headline: C&W Worldwide Names New CEO
summary: Cable & WirelessWorldwide PLC said Tuesday that it has appointed former Vodafone Group PLC executive Gavin Darby as its CEO to help turn around the U.K. telecommunications provider, which has issued several profit warnings following its demerger last year.

headline: Colombian FARC Rebels Pick Leader
summary: Colombia's main guerrilla group FARC named Timoleon Jimenez its new leader after the previous boss was killed earlier this month in a gunfight with the military.

headline: Navistar, Icahn Reach Agreement on Board
summary: Navistar International Corp. reached an agreement with investor Carl Icahn that requires the commercial truck maker to conduct annual elections of its directors and eliminate the current staggered terms for directors.

headline: BofA: Foreclosed Homes Selling Faster
summary: Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan said the bank is able to sell foreclosed houses faster than it had in the past as it tries to work through its pile of soured home loans.

headline: Euro Bucks the Underlying Trend
summary: The euro is far stronger than it should be, given that the euro zone is on life support.

headline: Monti to Present Plan Wednesday
summary: Prime Minister-designate Mario Monti said he will present his plan to govern Italy Wednesday morning. Monti didn't reveal his desired list of cabinet officials or any contents of his eventual program.

headline: Gold Ekes Out Gain
summary: Gold futures settled nearly flat as the dollar pared earlier gains against other currencies, restoring some of the precious metal's allure to foreign buyers.

headline: A Panel's Inquiry Clears Sino-Forest
summary: The independent committee investigating Chinese timber producer Sino-Forest said it found no evidence of fraud at the company and emphatically rejected allegations by a short-seller that sent shares down 75%.

headline: GM India Appoints New President
summary: General Motors India said it appointed Lowell Paddock as its new president and managing director effective on Jan. 1.

headline: BofA, Distressed-Debt Bettor Look to Trade in MF Claims
summary: Bank of America and hedge-fund manager Elliott Management are seeking court permission to buy and sell claims against MF Global. The requests will be heard Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Olympus Shares Jump
summary: Olympus shares rose 39% in the past two days on hopes that the camera maker can avoid having its shares delisted. But regulators are considering all options for penalizing the company.

headline: No Fund of Confidence in China's Banks
summary: The International Monetary Fund found that China's financial system should be able to weather shocks from falling real-estate prices or defaults by local government-financing vehicles. Investors should be skeptical.

headline: Display-Panel Businesses Wed
summary: Sony, Toshiba and Hitachi agreed to integrate their businesses of making display panels used in smartphones and tablet computers. The new entity, Japan Display, will start operating next spring.

headline: European Stocks Slide
summary: Italian 10-year bond yields climbed back above the critical 7% mark as concerns regarding the country's ability to push through vital austerity measures escalated, and consequently European stocks slid further into the red.

headline: India Urged to Ease Airline Rules
summary: Kingfisher Airlines Chairman Vijay Mallya called on the Indian government to allow foreign carriers to invest in India's ailing aviation industry. Kingfisher's loss more than doubled in the latest quarter.

headline: Inquiry Rejects Sino-Forest Fraud
summary: An independent panel forcefully rejected claims by research firm Muddy Waters LLC, which said the Chinese timber producer was a "near total fraud"—an accusation that sent shares down 80%.

headline: Codelco's Bid for Injunction Upheld
summary: A Chilean appeals court ratified an injunction state copper giant Corporacion Nacional del Cobre filed to halt Anglo American from selling a stake in its Sur mining complex.

headline: Temasek in Talks to Buy CCB Shares
summary: Bank of America is selling more of its shares in China's second-biggest bank by assets in a deal expected to generate an after-tax gain of $1.8 billion.

headline: China Urged to Address Online Security
summary: U.S. officials urged China to address the network-security and privacy concerns of Western companies, saying the rise of cloud computing and other network-based services conflicts with Chinese restrictions and its treatment of user data.

headline: Saks Posts Lower Profit, Higher Sales
summary: Saks reported improving sales and profit margins for its latest quarter, but the department-store operator's earnings dropped 51% from the prior year that saw a big tax-related gain.

headline: Euro's Loss Is Exporters' Gain
summary: Protecting capital on euro-zone equities markets has been a mug's game this year. But exporters in the region may offer investors some respite particularly if the euro continues to depreciate.

headline: Burberry Profits From Luxury Demand
summary: Luxury trench coat and designer-handbag retailer Burberry reported a 41% jump in first-half net profit, boosted by world-wide demand for luxury goods and an aggressive international expansion program.

headline: The Sick Men of Europe
summary: The euro zone managed to eke out growth of 0.2% in the third quarter, matching the lackluster second quarter. That looks disappointing when the U.S., Japan and the U.K. accelerated.

headline: Goldman to Maintain Accounting Method
summary: Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein said the company is not moving away from mark-to-market accounting.

headline: SocGen to Cut Hundreds of Jobs
summary: Société Générale plans to cut "several hundred" jobs in its French corporate and investment bank in 2012 as part of its push to conform with new capital rules, the company's trade union representatives said.

headline: Electrolux to Deepen Cost Cuts
summary: Home appliance maker Electrolux AB said it aims to cut costs by 5.1 billion Swedish kronor ($760 million) a year as it struggles to cope with falling consumer demand and rising raw material costs.

headline: Libya Oil Company Set to Resume Pumping—Official
summary: Waha Oil Co.—the last Libyan oil company yet to resume production following the end of that nation's war—is slated to resume pumping next month after a strike has been resolved, an official said.

headline: Neuberger Berman Raises Cash for Private-Equity Fund of Funds
summary: Neuberger Berman said it has raised $720 million for NB Crossroads 2010 Fund, the first private-equity fund of funds it has put together since it was spun out of Lehman Brothers in December 2008.

headline: Qatar Places Airbus Order
summary: Qatar Airways ordered 55 Airbus aircraft in a deal worth $6.4 billion at list prices, with options for 33 more planes, after it resolved an earlier disagreement with the European aircraft manufacturer.

headline: U.K. Inflation Falls to 5%
summary: The rate of inflation in the U.K. slowed more than expected in October, official data showed, as a supermarket price war helped offset higher household utility bills.

headline: BT Profit Jumps on Cost Cuts
summary: U.K. telecommunications company BT Group reported a 24% increase in second-quarter net profit on further cost cutting and reaffirmed its outlook for the year.

headline: Shanghai Sells New Local Bonds
summary: Shanghai sold China's first regional government bonds directly backed by local authorities at lower-than-expected yields, as investors embraced the new product.

headline: Tech Mahindra Profit Jumps 59%
summary: Tech Mahindra posted a 59% jump in quarterly net profit as a weaker Indian currency and profit from associate Satyam Computer Services eased the pressure of declining sales at the software exporter.

headline: Credit Suisse Boosts Private Bank
summary: Credit Suisse took a big step in its plans to boost the profitability of its private-banking activities, saying it will fold its Clariden Leu subsidiary into the rest of the bank, eliminating brands that have been around for more than 250 years.

headline: India State Fuel Retailers to Cut Gasoline Prices
summary: India's state-run fuel retailers will cut local gasoline prices Wednesday, the first price reduction since January 2009, executives from two fuel companies said.

headline: India's Troubled Airlines
summary: As Kingfisher Airlines announced heavy losses Tuesday, a look at it and some of the country's other troubled airlines. In pictures. See related article.

headline: Adani Seeks to Expand Australia Port
summary: India's Adani Group is seeking regulatory approval for a new coal terminal at Abbot Point in Australia's Queensland state, which would potentially raise its coal exports from the port by 70%.

headline: EasyJet to Pay Dividend as Profits Soar
summary: Budget carrier easyJet confirmed it would return £195 million to shareholders as it reported an 86% rise in full-year profit, though it warned the macro-economic environment remains challenging as consumer confidence weakens.

headline: Tata October Global Vehicle Sales Rise 10%
summary: Tata Motors said its global sales in October rose 10% from a year earlier to 95,789 vehicles.

headline: India Shares Fall to More Than Three-Week Low
summary: Indian shares fell to their lowest in more than three weeks, largely due to poor corporate earnings fueling worries about slowing economic growth.

headline: Asian Shares Fall
summary: Asian stock markets ended mostly lower Tuesday amid concerns over whether newly formed governments in Italy and Greece can contain their debt crisis as Spanish and Italian government-bond yields climbed.

headline: NTT DoCoMo Still in iPhone Talks
summary: NTT DoCoMo is still in discussions with Apple to offer the iPhone in Japan, but certain conditions make it difficult for the carrier to bring the popular smartphone onto its network, its top executive said.

headline: Steel Authority of India Signs Initial Pact With Oman Oil
summary: Steel Authority of India and Oman Oil Co. S.A.O.C. have signed an initial pact to jointly set up a steel plant in Oman with an estimated investment of $3 billion, India's steel minister said.

headline: China Inspects Rare-Earth Production
summary: China has started a new round of inspections aimed at strengthening the monitoring of rare-earth production, in a sign that Beijing is likely to continue to keep a tight control over production of the key minerals.

headline: LinkedIn Opens India R&D Center
summary: LinkedIn has opened a research and development center in the southern Indian state of Karnataka, the professional social-networking site's first such office outside North America.

headline: German Growth Accelerates
summary: German economic growth accelerated in the third quarter of this year in line with expectations, data from the Federal Statistics Office showed.

headline: Fashionandyou.com Co-Owners Raise $40 Million
summary: E-commerce companies Smile Group Venture and Goldsquare Sales India, co-owners of the website fashionandyou.com, said they have raised about $40 million from a group of investors including Norwest Venture Partners and Intel Capital.

headline: Intel Capital Invests in India's Happiest Minds Technologies
summary: The investment fund of chip maker Intel didn't disclose the investment amount in a press release, but said the Indian firm was one of 10 Asian companies which received a total of $40 million capital.

headline: SBI Says Kingfisher Airlines Has Not Sought More Debt
summary: State Bank of India said there is no question of restructuring the debt of loss-making Kingfisher Airlines as the carrier hasn't defaulted on loan repayments.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: Navy personnel during an exercise, a Congress party rally in Allahabad, jail inmates at a computer class in Gujarat, and more.

headline: French Economy Returns to Growth
summary: The French economy returned to growth in the third quarter, official statistics showed, providing some reassurance that the country will meet its deficit reduction targets for 2011.

headline: Tata Motors Posts 16% Profit Drop
summary: Tata Motors said its second-quarter profit fell 16%, hurt by higher raw-material costs, a foreign currency loss and slowing auto sales in India.

headline: Tower Bersama to Buy Indosat Cell Towers
summary: Indonesia's PT Tower Bersama Infrastructure said Tuesday it has signed a preliminary agreement to buy the cellular towers of PT Indosat.

headline: The Vanishing Artist
summary: Liu Bolin, known as the "Vanishing Artist," becomes "invisible" in his latest artworks by using optical illusions.

headline: The Navy in Pictures
summary: The Indian Navy demonstrated several exercise routines ahead of the upcoming President's Fleet Review in December. Some snapshots.

headline: Australia Seeks End of India Uranium Ban
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Julia Gillard signaled an end to a decades-long ban on selling uranium to India, to take advantage of demand for cleaner-burning fuels and offset a potential drop in sales to Japan.

headline: Future Group, Japan's Lawson Name Consultants for Retail Supply JV
summary: India's Future Group and Japanese convenience-store operator Lawson have appointed consultants to conduct due diligence for forming a retail supply chain joint venture, the Economic Times reported.

headline: Coca-Cola to Invest $2 Billion Over Five Years in India
summary: Coca-Cola said it will invest $2 billion in India over five years, as the soda giant and its bottling partners plan to spend $30 billion to build capacities and on marketing in emerging economies.

headline: IMF Calls for China Banking Revamp
summary: China needs to revamp its banking system to head off a "steady build-up of financial sector vulnerabilities," the IMF said.

headline: Report: Prescription-Drug Sponsors Lack Data
summary: Companies that administer government-funded prescription drug plans for seniors have no way of knowing whether the drugs they cover are approved by Medicare, a new report by federal investigators has found.

headline: GAIL Looking to Buy Majority Stake in BG Group Unit
summary: GAIL India is looking to buy a majority stake in BG Group PLC local unit Gujarat Gas, the Economic Times reported.

headline: Fortress of Collectibles
summary: St. Mark's Place isn't on my normal city rounds, since I'm rarely in need of a new tattoo and my vinyl record collection is up to date. However, there is one emporium that draws me back—St. Mark's Comics.

headline: For Tech's Elite, Mobile Gaming Is Big Play
summary: Mobile gaming is the new gold rush, with venture capital firms pouring money into the sector and developers working overtime to create the next Zygna.

headline: Deficit Deal Is a Moving Target
summary: With time running out for Congress' special deficit-reduction committee, Democrats Monday were preparing a new proposal that would inch the two sides closer together on the crucial issue of taxes.

headline: Prescription for Kids:  Turn Out That Light
summary: Thank you for the essay "Waking Up to Young Kids' Sleep Troubles" (Review, Nov. 5), which illuminates one of the biggest areas of collateral damage created from our children's ever-expanding digital universe: less sleep

headline: The Casual NBA Fan Is Half Out the Door
summary: The more this lockout drags on, the more the fair-weather hoops fan slips away.

headline: Investors Still Wary at Italy Bond Sale
summary: Italy was forced to offer investors a euro-era record interest rate to place five-year government bonds, highlighting doubts over the new government's ability to rein in Rome's large debt load.

headline: McGurn: Crony Capitalism, Chicago-Style
summary: The new economy: Tax hikes for all, tax relief for the well-connected, campaign contributions for the politicians.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Nov. 15, 2011

headline: Lockout Lets Players Act Out Fantasies
summary: The NBA lockout has left hundreds of media-savvy athletes without their usual day jobs. Some are using the free time to pursue business interests that may better prepare them for life after basketball.

headline: China Copper Hunger Fades
summary: For a clue as to why copper is lagging behind many other commodities, investors could look to Wenzhou, China.

headline: Brady, Patriots Smother Jets
summary: Tom Brady torches the Jets for 300-plus passing yards and three touchdowns

headline: Marathon Arguments Hark Back to 19th Century
summary: The health law has restored the Supreme Court's once-hefty appetite for debate.

headline: Steps to Prevent a Second Heart Attack
summary: For heart-attack survivors, eliminating copayments for prescriptions can improve the chances of avoiding a second attack, a new study found. The results prompted Aetna to announce a new benefits plan that will enable survivors to get certain medicines at no or reduced out-of-pocket costs.

headline: Possible New Weapon Against Brain Tumors
summary: Scientists have developed a new cancer-killing virus that significantly prolonged the life of mice with glioblastoma, an aggressive form of brain cancer in humans.

headline: Anadarko Raises Colorado Oil Tally
summary: Anadarko said land it controls in northern Colorado may hold more than a billion barrels of recoverable oil and natural gas.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: Cleaning Out Zuccotti Park
summary: By Matthew Kaminski  A couple older protesters and a few younger people milled around, and one hollered in the direction of a group of policemen, "We'll be back."

headline: Train to Neverland
summary: California's railway gets more fantastic all the time.

headline: Olympus Banks Await Probe
summary: Olympus's banks said they will wait for more details to emerge before deciding what action to take regarding the company's credit lines.

headline: United Pilots Turn Up Heat Over Training
summary: United Airlines pilots, still simmering over what they call "inadequate" training, have ratcheted up pressure on the carrier by circulating to members of Congress a highly critical 101-page report by their union.

headline: Why the Marlins' Uniform Change Could Change Their Luck
summary: The Florida Marlins have radically changed their color scheme—which, based on recent history, might lead to dramatic improvement on the field.

headline: The Seahawks Bet on Plus-Size 'D'
summary: The Seattle Seahawks are just 3-6, but they may be on to an innovative concept: bigger, not faster, players on defense.

headline: J.P. Morgan Backs Loan Guarantor in China
summary: J.P. Morgan is investing about $200 million to help set up a financial company that will guarantee loans to small Chinese firms, which have traditionally struggled to get credit from the country's banks.

headline: Ex-Boyfriend Backs Cain Accuser
summary: The former boyfriend of a woman who accused Herman Cain of an unwanted sexual advance in the late 1990s came forward Monday to support the woman's statement that she and Mr. Cain knew each other.

headline: Steven Landsburg: A Short Econ Quiz for the Super Committee
summary: Why an extra trillion in 'irresponsible' deficit spending can't become 'responsible' if paid for by higher taxes.

headline: Anatomy of an L.A. Museum's Fall Affair
summary: Museum of Contemporary Art Los Angeles' fall gala was an evening curated by the Yugoslavian-born performance artist Marina Abramovic.

headline: Two Populist Movements Rooted in Same Soil
summary: A deeper look at those who sympathize with the tea party and occupy movements suggests they are more accurately seen as expressions of economic anxiety and anger that have spread into the political mainstream.

headline: Feds Probe Comptroller's Fund Raising
summary: Federal investigators have launched a probe into possible campaign-finance irregularities in New York City Comptroller John Liu's fund-raising operation, people familiar with the matter confirmed.

headline: Photos of the Day: Nov. 15
summary: In today's pictures, employees check devices on an Airbus cargo plane in Germany, an elephant reaches out in India, doctors strike in Barcelona, and more.

headline: The Fed's Low Rates Enabled MF Global
summary: Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke claims that the collapse of MF Global Ltd. is "an idiosyncratic case" that hasn't caused "any impact on financial stability" ("Fed Lowers Its Jobs Forecast," U.S. News, Nov. 3). Idiosyncratic? Let's ask the following question: How was MF Global able to leverage itself 40 to 1 so it could load up on distressed sovereign debt?

headline: Give Credit to Credit-Default Swaps
summary: In the current fragile markets, taking away bond insurance will only drive away investors, increasing borrowing costs for indebted nations and putting pressure on already-strained banks.

headline: Karzai Seeks Long-Term Plan
summary: Afghan President Hamid Karzai is seeking to bolster his negotiating position in talks with the U.S. at a gathering this week of some 2,000 delegates from the provinces.

headline: Rivkin and Casey: ObamaCare and the Limits of Government
summary: When asked if the health law was constitutional, then-Speaker Nancy Pelosi sneered, 'Are you serious?' Now the Supreme Court has decided it's a worthy question.

headline: At UniCredit, Job Cuts and Share Sale
summary: UniCredit, one of Europe's largest banks, announced a €7.5 billion capital increase and a shake-up of its investment-banking operations after the Italian lender reported a €10.64 billion loss for the third quarter.

headline: Loan Backer's Cash Runs Low
summary: The Federal Housing Administration's cash reserves have fallen so low that there is a "close to 50%" chance the agency could run out of money and require a taxpayer bailout in the next year, according to a report.

headline: Interview Excerpts: Ahmed Chalabi
summary: Ahmed Chalabi, president of the Iraqi National Congress, spoke via telephone from Baghdad with The Wall Street Journal's Jay Solomon on Oct. 30. Read selected excerpts from the interview.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Nov. 15, 2011

headline: Buffett Bets $10.7 Billion in Biggest Tech Foray
summary: Warren Buffett plowed $10.7 billion into the shares of IBM, making a massive bet on a technology services company after years of eschewing tech stocks.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Michael Barone on why the tea party and the 1960s peace movement have a lot in common.

headline: Words and the Performers Who Love Them
summary: Each week in Curtain Raisers, we invite a New York-based theater artist to attend a new show and discuss the results. On Thursday, actor Ben Shenkman opted for a preview of Theresa Rebeck's comedy "Seminar."

headline: The Nightmare of Real Things
summary: Featuring astronauts, terrorists and travelers, Don DeLillo's collection of short stories, "The Angel Esmeralda," describes the condition of modern estrangement. Sam Sacks reviews.

headline: Forint Falls as Fears on Hungary Mount
summary: Hungary's currency traded near all-time lows against the euro as fears mounted that the country's sovereign debt could be downgraded to junk-bond status because of slowing growth and unorthodox government economic policies.

headline: Rhodium's Rare Opportunity
summary: In terms of rarity, rhodium makes gold look like paper dollars. Yet, at just under $1,700 an ounce, rhodium is now cheaper than gold and, more importantly, has disconnected from its cousin platinum.

headline: Subway Repairs to Delay Night Trains
summary: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to start shutting down long stretches of busy subway lines at night for brief periods early next year, a step it says will help workers do maintenance and reduce the need for delays at other times.

headline: On the Sad Decline of Proud Liberals
summary: At last! A Journal article that reveals the usurpation of that sacred word "liberal." Thank you Mario Vargas Llosa ("Literature and the Search for Liberty," op-ed, Nov. 8).

headline: Brooklyn Church Thinks Mixed Use
summary: The historic New Baptist Temple in Brooklyn will team up with a real-estate developer to repurpose the 118-year-old building into a mixed-use facility.

headline: Stalled Hoboken Arts Complex Moves Ahead
summary: A five-phase plan to transform an aging industrial zone in Hoboken into a bustling artistic hub is showing the first signs of life in more than three years.

headline: Stirring the Pot to Help Start-Ups
summary: One by one, old-school food manufacturing plants such as A.L. Bazzini Co., Stella D'oro and Sabra have left New York City over the past few years. Others, though, are moving into the void, boosted in part by a growing support system: food incubators.

headline: Georgian Conversion
summary: This two-bedroom apartment in central London's Marylebone neighborhood has recently been extended.

headline: Ackermann to Leave Deutsche
summary: Deutsche Bank said that CEO Josef Ackermann won't take over as chairman of the supervisory board when he steps down in May, and it is proposing Allianz financial chief Paul Achleitner for the position instead.

headline: Israel Studies Plan to Detain Illegal Migrants
summary: Israel is considering controversial new legislation to rebuff a surging tide of African asylum-seekers through lengthy detention time.

headline: Europe Economy Weakens
summary: Europe's fragile economy showed deepening distress as industrial production dropped across the euro zone, dimming hopes leaders will be able to resolve the debt crisis.

headline: Paulson Shifts Tack in Gold, Banks
summary: Billionaire hedge-fund manager John Paulson, retrenching after a miserable first half, slashed his holdings in SPDR Gold Trust and Citigroup.
